xmlkeyword.term: Eiffel Editor, Code Browsing and Navigation

paragraph.paragraph: EiffelEnvision's index.xmlEiffel Editor provides the same code browsing and navigation extensions to the Visual Studio .NET vxurfCodeTextEditorWindow 0 Core Editor found in Microsoft languages such as Visual C#, Visual Basic .NET and Visual C++. This information in the documentation describes the index.xmlEiffel Editor's extended set of code browsing and navigation features.

The EiffelEnvision Eiffel editor supports and expands upon Visual Studio .NET core editor vxtskOutliningCode 0 Outlining Code abilities. By default, all /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *Eiffel classes are automatically outlined. This means that any edits made in the editor will automatically adjust the outline regions as you type. There are a number of outlining options available from the editor Outlining context submenu. Please refer to the vxtskOutliningCode 0 Outlining Code documentation, in the Outlining context submenu, for an explanation of each of the code outlining functions.

The Eiffel editor provides a special operation for the Collapse to Definitions outlining function. Instead of simply collapsing the code to the signature definitions, as in many other language editors in Visual Studio .NET, the Eiffel editor retains any /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *preconditions and obsolete messages. /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *Preconditions and obsolete messages are retained because of their considered importance to the feature as code documentation.

When editing /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *Eiffel classes , a feature drop down list will appear at the top at the top of the editor, containing a list of features currently in the class in view. For every feature, there is an associated icon indicating the declared feature_type_icons*feature type. The feature list acts as an index for the code. Selecting a feature from the list will cause the editor to jump and center the view on the associated feature.

When editing or browsing the Eiffel code, the feature list will update itself to indicate where the caret is currently positioned in the editor. If the visible list item becomes gray, this is an indication that the caret is between feature declarations and cannot associate a feature with it. If the editor caret is currently positioned inside of a feature declaration, the feature's name will be an active item in the features list.
As a final note, the features list is updated in real-time, so changing any feature's name or its declaration type will immediately be reflected in the list.

For /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *Eiffel classes opened in index.xml project_editing *project associated editing mode (opened from within an EiffelEnvision project), Go To Definition (shortcut F12) will be available from the Eiffel editor context menu. Go to definition attempts to locate an Eiffel definition for a /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml feature *feature or /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *class under the editor's caret. Selecting to go to a definition will produce one of 3 outcomes.
An Eiffel definition will be located; the class file will be opened and the located feature highlighted, in the editor.
The located definition was from a .NET assembly; the t*Object Browser will be opened and the definition expanded and centered in view.
No definition could be found.

There are many reasons why go to definition may not find the definition you requested.
Check the class you are trying to perform the go to definition action on for syntax errors.
Check if the class you are trying to perform the go to definition action on has been compiled into the project on the last url*build.
The expression may be too complex to efficiently extract a definition from.

For /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *Eiffel classes opened in index.xml project_editing *project associated editing mode (opened from within an EiffelEnvision project), Synchronize Class View will be available from the Eiffel editor context menu. Synchronize Class View attempts to locate the feature at the caret's current position in the vxurfClassViewWindow 0 Class View .
Note: The class view is a compiled representation of your project(s). This means synchronizing with the vxurfClassViewWindow 0 Class View will not synchronize for any features added and not compiled into your project.
